1. Wondo belongs in the record books

There was actually a game going on in Portland on Saturday. Honestly. But as the final whistle sounded in the 1-1 tie between the Portland Timbers and the San Jose Earthquakes, one man was the center of attention: Chris Wondolowski.
With both teams' postseason fates already sealed, it turned into the Wondo show in PDX. Two goals away from setting an MLS record for the most goals scored in the regular season, Wondolowski struck early to tie Roy Lassiter's record (which had lasted since the MLS' inaugural season in 1996) and the rest of the game turned into #WondoWatch.
The man of the hour, if not the man of the season, had a great opportunity to set the record in the 66th minute. Wondolowski's back-post header hit the side-netting and as he looked longingly to the sky, he knew the chance to score a 28th goal of the regular season was slipping away from him. And it did. But that took nothing away from his incredible achievement, with Wondo proud to go down in history alongside Lassiter:
"I know how hard it is, how great of a legend Roy Lassiter is. To share a record with him and to always be linked with him, I couldn't be happier." Yet Wondolowski does now hold one MLS record on his own. He has the league's all-time record for most combined goals and assists in a single season. Wondo finished the 2012 regular season with seven assists in addition to his 27 goals, beating Jason Kreis' 1999 total of 18 goals and 15 assists. One factor has been consistent throughout Wondo's goal-scoring exploits – the role of his teammates. It was quite fitting that Steven Lenhart allowed him to break into the record books and when Donovan Ricketts clattered the mischievous forward for a penalty, it kind of summed up San Jose's season. The 'Quakes players knew if they worked their tails off and got the ball to Wondo, he would finish —his record of 66 goals in 104 games over four seasons since joining San Jose is testament to that. Now Wondo and the 'Quakes turn their attention to the playoffs. With the Supporters' Shield under one arm and a new stadium fast approaching, an MLS Cup would cap off a marvelous season. In the conference semifinals they face the LA Galaxy or the Vancouver Whitecaps, who play their Knockout Round match on Wednesday at the Home Depot Center. Despite the 'Caps scraping into the final playoff place in the west, they're about the only team to have San Jose's number in 2012. Vancouver's direct style of play at home on their artificial turf has caused San Jose's back line problems, with two 2-1 wins at BC Place showcasing Vancouver's dominance. San Jose have beaten LA 3-2 and 4-3 and looked incredibly comfortable in a 2-2 draw at Buck Shaw just over a week ago. LA seemed to be scared of San Jose's attacking talent, with Lenhart and Alan Gordon battering the Galaxy into submission and Wondolowski picking up the pieces to devastating effect. Like only he can. JPW

2. Thierry Henry doesn't believe in Halloween

You never know quite what you're going to get when you interview Thierry Henry after a game. He can be disgusted by a win, delighted with a draw, or just refuse to speak (in the open locker-room system of MLS rules, this effectively means sitting with a towel on his head until everyone goes away...). On Saturday afternoon the Red Bulls beat Philadelphia Union 3-0 to secure a third-place seeding that will see them face DC United in the Eastern Conference semi-final, starting next weekend. It was the Red Bulls' second successive clean sheet and, more crucially, their first away win since May, and Henry got in on the act with a typically deft chip over the keeper for the second goal. So was he happy? The answer was abrupt:

"First half yes. Second half no."

This was pretty understandable. Having taken a 2-0 lead into half-time, New York were rocked on their heels for the start of the second half and had Carlos Valdes' looping header dropped under instead of on to the bar the result could have been different. Kenny Cooper's second goal of the day, to make it 3-0, visibly deflated the home side in the closing stages, to the delight of a large and vocal New York traveling support, but Philadelphia knew that had Jack McInerney in particular showed more composure at times, he'd have got more joy against the slow central duo of Markus Holgersson and Rafael Marquez, rather than just offering up a blueprint for other, sharper sides.

But with victory and third place assured, was Henry at least relieved to avoid a possible wild-card game in New Jersey on Wednesday night – never the easiest sell in the world, let alone in the potential recent aftermath of a hurricane, and on Halloween?

"I don't know about Halloween, man – this is football. For me, there is no Halloween in football. Halloween or not, we're going to have to perform, crowd or not. Obviously it's way better when they [the crowd] were like they were against Kansas City last week."

Had New York slipped up in Philly, they could have found themselves in a midweek wild-card play off game in a very surreal atmosphere with plenty of potential for horror, whether Henry believes in Halloween or not. As it is, Red Bull Arena can expect a much better turnout on Saturday night when DC United mark their return to the playoffs with a visit to their most heated rivals.

They'll do so facing Kenny Cooper on goalscoring form. His two on Saturday took him just a goal shy of Juan Pablo Angel's 19-goal season scoring record, though according to Henry he still needs to do more: "You've got to keep the ball better, and also pass the ball to your teammates." He prefaced this with a chuckle, then added: "But...18 goals. And we need those goals – and more."

It's hard to do justice to how high Henry's eyebrows were raised as he spelled this out – as unpredictable as Henry the interview subject can be, Henry the teammate is predictably exacting in the standards he demands of those around him. One of the striking sights in the league this season has been Henry pointing and gesticulating around the field as he points Cooper to where he wants him to run next.

With Portland no longer paying part of his wages next year and a likely cap-stretching wage increase on the table, Cooper may be on his way in the offseason. But Saturday's result confirmed that he and Henry will still be together at least a week into November. Well past Halloween, then. GP

3. Nobody wants to finish second

If it wasn't Chicago slipping out of the automatic conference semi-final places into the wild-card game by drawing at home, or Real Salt Lake failing to beat Vancouver, it was Seattle arriving in LA needing only a point for second place in the West, with home advantage against RSL on the line, only to give up a goal in the last five minutes, to the Galaxy's Mike Magee.

.

Magee may be more used to playing second fiddle to the Galaxy's stars but come the playoffs he's a talismanic figure – scoring three times in their post-season run to MLS Cup last year and popping up in the last few minutes of the last MLS game of the regular season to ensure that his team will not be the only big hitter doing things the hard way in their quest for MLS Cup.

The Galaxy must play six games if they are to win the MLS Cup, and more than likely three of them will be on the road. Had the Sounders won (and they were 6-0 up on the Galaxy over their previous two games this season) they would not only have had home-field advantage over the Salt Lake team that beat them at the same stage last year, but over four of the five Eastern Conference teams, should they have made it to MLS Cup. We hardly need to explain the advantages of a full house in a home game for the Sounders, but as it stands they join LA in knowing that any possible MLS glory is more than likely going to be won on the road.

Compare that to the four games (three of them at home) that LA played in winning it all last year. You'd think teams would be falling over themselves to take home-field advantage, but though the Sounders made a lot of chances on Sunday night, the game slipped by and now they face a tougher route to the MLS Cup they covet. Even worse for them was the sight of Eddie Johnson limping off, clutching his hamstring, at the end of the first half.

The Galaxy have injury worries of their own of course – AJ De La Garza may not play on Thursday and despite playing for 90 minutes on Sunday night, and showing his usual vision and touch, Landon Donovan looked way off the pace as he tried to play through the pain barrier and force through his comeback from injury. David Beckham looked marginally more involved, but lasted just over an hour before being hauled off. The Galaxy have until Thursday to recover for their wild-card game against Vancouver. No prizes for finishing second in that one. GP

4. The Fire may be running out of fuel

With both teams assured of a playoff spot going into the regular-season finale, you could forgive Chicago and DC United for taking their foot off the gas. But that didn't happen. It was a blood-and-thunder affair at Toyota Park, with the conference seeding on the line. Chicago took the lead and would have expected to kick on and grab the vital three points to put them straight through to the playoff semifinals. Yet they faltered, their offense once again misfiring when it counted most.

.

They now face Houston (9pm ET, Wednesday, Toyota Park) in the Knockout Round of the playoffs, after winning just once in their last five. Three losses from their last four games have undone the good work that saw Chicago scrapping for the top spot in the East just last month. After creating several clear-cut chances they just couldn't find the finishing touch against United.

Chicago weren't widely favored to make the playoffs in 2012. But they're worthy of their spot, having put in competent defensive displays and benefited from the clinical finishing of Chris Rolfe and Sherjill MacDonald down the stretch. But that went missing on Saturday, when MacDonald was twice thwarted one-on-one by DC's brilliant Bill Hamid.

Even though they grabbed a point, the Fire's confidence will be low after a less than impressive finish to the regular season. But that's all it was. Chicago made it to the postseason, now everyone is equal and the past means nothing. The sooner Frank Klopas' side can forget their misfiring performance against DC, the better. And having Houston visit so soon can only be a good thing. If Chicago weren't creating chances, then that would be a bigger problem. But forcing Hamid to make eight saves, some of them spectacular, suggests there isn't too much cause for concern – other than that the pressure seemed to get to Chicago's forwards, with a shot at the No2 seed on the line.

Both the Dynamo and Chicago are built on solid defensive platforms and I expect a tight, cagey affair that could well go to overtime and penalties. The Fire will need that offensive spark to return, and quickly, if they're going to extend their season. Chicago's 2012 record against Houston should fill them with confidence, featuring a win and two draw's in their three encounters. But in the postseason, that means nothing. JPW

5. And then there were 10…

This week we say goodbye to the nine teams who are out of the running for the MLS Cup, as from here on out we focus on the 10 teams who've made the postseason. But here's a quick summary of the sides that didn't make it to the dance, and how they fared in 2012.

New England had a great pre-season and ended their campaign with back-to-back wins, as first Chicago and then Montreal (on the road, 1-0 on Saturday) were dispatched. The bit in between was the problem. Under-performers and widespread defensive lapses riddled Jay Heaps' first season in charge. Montreal left the 2012 scene with their heads held high after a strong debut MLS season saw them just shy of the playoff spots. There was also the memory of some record-breaking crowds welcoming soccer to Quebec – with just a dash of Italian flavor as the season went on.

As for Chivas USA, hope springs eternal, but another disappointing campaign sees them propping up the West after scoring just 24 goals. However, with Jorge Vergara now the sole owner and plenty of front-office changes, the Goats could be at the start of something beautiful. Let's hope so, for the franchise's sake. FC Dallas almost became the comeback kings but a horrible stretch of injuries curtailed what many thought would be a promising season for Schellas Hyndman's side. They pushed Vancouver all the way for the final playoff spot out West but came up just short. David Ferreira returned in terrific form to spearhead FCD's attack, but a 14-game winless streak in the middle of the season did the damage. Also, they need the old Brek Shea back, fast. The two sides played out a frenetic 2-2 draw on Sunday night, with Chivas coming back from 2-0 down. Too little, too late though.

A team spiraling out of control since the start of the season, the Philadelphia Union, hugely underachieved in 2012. But with Peter Nowak mindlessly dismantling his successful playoff team from the previous season and then leaving, what else could you expect? John Hackworth brought some continuity to the Union and the youngsters thrown in at the deep end will be better for it in 2013. However it seems as if Freddy Adu won't be joining them.

The Portland Timbers were another side who underachieved, with John Spencer paying the ultimate price. He brought in the likes of Kris Boyd and Danny Mwanga to help the Timbers make the playoffs. Instead, they crumbled. The only solace for the Timbers Army was a Cascadia Cup title and with new head coach Caleb Porter coming in next season, a big improvement is expected in the Rose City.

The Porter experiment will be interesting to follow, just as the Oscar Pareja project was in Colorado. The Rapids flew out of the traps in 2012, with three wins from their first four and Tony Cascio looking like a rookie of the year candidate. They played attractive, attacking soccer and completely contrasted the Colorado of the past with a fluid 4-3-3 system. But injuries to key players and defensive lapses cost Pareja, with five straight losses in July denting their playoff hopes. But a morale-boosting 2-0 win over Houston on Saturday shows Pareja should be given more time to implement his style on Colorado.

What more is there to say about Toronto FC? They started the season with a league-record nine-game losing streak and finished it without a win in 14. Do the math – that doesn't leave many games to rack up points. Head coach Paul Mariner plugged the gaps Aron Winter left behind but it's been another season to forget for the Reds. They ended their season with a loss to the Crew – perhaps the one team who can feel legitimately aggrieved to not be in the postseason. It's a shame the Crew didn't acquire the forwards Jairo Arrieta and Federico Higuain sooner – if so, they wouldn't have made this section and they'd definitely be in the playoffs. The Crew came up just short but with some solid recruitment over the offseason, they're sure to have success in 2013. JPW

New York is bracing itself for the biggest storm ever to hit the east coast of America – Hurricane Sandy – which has been described as a "Frankenstorm". Public transport services started shutting down on 28 October and will remain closed until the hurricane has passed and the damage has been assessed. Where does this leave travellers from the UK?

I am due to fly out – what are my chances of getting there?

Non-existant on 29 October and mixed on 30 October. Airlines have cancelled about 7,000 flights so far.

BA has cancelled all flights to and from the east coast for 29 October, including those to New York, Washington, Boston, Baltimore and Philadelphia (with the exception of BA238 from Boston). Virgin Atlantic has also cancelled all flights to and from New York, Washington and Boston on 29 October.

So what are my rights?

Under European law, if you are flying to or from the EU with a EU-based airline and your flight is cancelled, the airline is obliged to offer you a choice: you can either cancel your booking and get a refund, or rebook on to a different flight.

If your flights are with a non-EU airline you may only be offered help with the flight from the UK to the US, although the trade association ABTA says non-EU airlines are rescheduling passengers on to different flights – in some cases with a fee for the fare difference – or refunding those who have had their flights cancelled for both outbound and inbound journeys.

If you are stranded and booked with a EU airline, under the EU rules you should also be entitled to refreshments and meals within reason, the cost of two phone calls and, if necessary, overnight accommodation. Keep receipts for the costs you incur.

However, you will not be entitled to compensation ranging from €250 to €600 under EU air passenger regulation 261. The Civil Aviation Authority, which enforces the rules in the UK, says that because cancellations caused by Hurricane Sandy will be treated as an extraordinary circumstance, affected passengers will not be entitled to additional compensation.

What should I do?

Bob Atkinson of TravelSupermarket.com says the first step is to check the status of your flight on your airline's website, and see what help and advice it is offering – this will vary from airline to airline, including the length of time you have to rebook your flight.

If your flight is part of an ATOL-backed holiday your tour operator will look after you, making sure you have accommodation and transport as soon as possible. However, if you have booked independently you need to make sure the other parts of your trip – hotel rooms, car, etc – are cancelled, otherwise your booking will be treated as a no-show and you will be charged the full amount. Atkinson warns you may still face cancellation charges, ranging from 0% to 100% of the full price regardless of the circumstances.

Will my travel insurance pay out if my flight is delayed or cancelled?

If you bought the policy after the hurricane was announced, you will not be covered. If you bought it before and the delay goes beyond 12 hours your insurer should offer a payout, according to Martin Rothwell of travel insurance brokers World First Travel. However, check the small print of your policy as cover varies, and some cheaper policies do not cover delays or cancellations.

I'm due to fly later in the week but want to cancel – can I get a refund?

Only if your ticket or airline allows for that. The Foreign and Commonwealth Office has not warned against travelling to the US, so travel insurers will not pay out if you want to cancel your holiday or journey.

What is BA saying?

BA is offering passengers due to travel between 26 and 31 October the option of changing their travel plans. Those who booked through a travel agent or tour operator should contact them directly; those who booked through BA's website or call centre should call 0844 493 0787 (between 06:00 and 20:00 local time) in the UK, or 1 800 247 9297 (07:00-01:00 local time) in the US.

If you are booked on to a cancelled British Airways flight you can either rebook on to another BA flight at a later date at no extra charge and subject to availability, or cancel your booking and claim a refund to the original form of repayment.

What about Virgin Atlantic?

Virgin is warning passengers on flights that have been cancelled to not travel to the airport and instead contact their travel agent or provider to rebook on the next available flight. Passengers who booked direct with the airline should call its flight disruption line on + 44 (0) 844 209 8711 in the UK, or 1-800-862-8621 in the US.

Virgin is warning that because so many aircraft are out of position it may take a little while before things return to normal, but it will try to book seats with other carriers to speed the process for stranded passengers.

Passengers of cancelled flights who have not started their trip can also claim a refund from their original point of sale, rebook on a later date or rebook on a Virgin Atlantic flight to or from another destination.

Daniel Day-Lewis has put paid to one of the most infamous stage anecdotes of all time, revealing that he didn't literally see his late father's ghost when playing Hamlet.

The double Oscar winner played the Dane at the National Theatre in 1989 , but quit the production mid-performance and has not returned to the theatre since. He subsequently explained that he had seen his father, the poet Cecil Day-Lewis, who died when his son was 15, standing on the stage staring at him.

However, in an interview published last week , Day-Lewis insisted that he was speaking more metaphorically than literally.

"I may have said a lot of things in the immediate aftermath," he told Time Magazine, "and to some extent I probably saw my father's ghost every night, because of course if you're working in a play like Hamlet you explore everything through your own experience."

He continued: "That correspondence between father and son, or the son and the father who is no longer alive, played a huge part in that experience. So yes, of course, it was communication with my own dead father, but I don't remember seeing any ghosts of my father on that dreadful night!"

Day-Lewis is renowned for the rigour with which he approaches roles, often immersing himself in a character's lifestyle and remaining in role even when the cameras aren't shooting. He famously trained as a butcher before Gangs of New York and caught pneumonia on set because he refused to wear modern thermal clothing.

In preparation for his latest performance as Abraham Lincoln in Stephen Speilberg's biopic, he sent his co-star Sally Field text messages signed "Yours, A."

After leaving the theatre during Hamlet, Day-Lewis collapsed backstage. His understudy Jeremy Northam completed the run and Day-Lewis didn't act at all for several years afterwards.

The actor has often been asked about his experiences; in 2003, he told the Guardian that it was "a very vivid, almost hallunicatory moment in which I was engaged in a dialogue with my father … but that wasn't the reason I had to leave the stage. I had to leave the stage because I was an empty vessel. I had nothing in me, nothing to say, nothing to give."

The chief executive of Trinity Mirror has vowed to investigate claims that a former business partner of Sophie, Countess of Wessex, had his phone hacked by the Sunday Mirror more than 10 years ago.

Simon Fox said Trinity Mirror had not been contacted by Murray Harkin, but it had "no alternative other than to fully investigate" reports at the weekend that his phone was hacked.

The Financial Times reported on Saturday that the Metropolitan police were assessing claims by Harkin that a 2001 Sunday Mirror article was published after his phone was hacked.

Harkin is the fifth individual to complain about hacking by Trinity Mirror titles – four others, including former England football manager Sven-Göran Eriksson, last week lodged civil damages claims with the high court.

"Whilst we have not yet been contacted by Mr Harkin, or anyone associated with him and have no reason to believe that there is any substance to this accusation, I have asked for our inquiry team to include this new allegation in their review," Fox said in an internal email to staff on Monday morning, seen by MediaGuardian.

"I am absolutely clear that if any wrong-doing happened within the company, then we have no alternative other than to fully investigate and surface it."

Harkin reportedly suspects he was followed while on holiday abroad by somebody who could only have discovered his whereabouts from listening to his voicemails.

Trinity Mirror announced last Wednesday that it had launched an internal investigation, headed by the chairman David Grigson, into the hacking claims which led to more than 20% being wiped off the company's share price last week.

In his email on Monday, Fox said: "I will work alongside David on this, but his assistance will enable me to devote most of my time to Trinity Mirror's future, rather than allegations about its past."

The inquiry into past allegations comes amid reports that a secret dossier on phone hacking has been prepared by concerned investors, which claims the practice was organised on a "systemic scale".

According to the Independent on Sunday, the dossier names six reporters from the Daily Mirror and the People who, it claims, regularly hacked phones.

Investors commissioned the investigation during the Leveson inquiry to evaluate the commercial risk it posed to the company. Former senior reporters at the company's national titles are said to have been the sources of the information.

A spokesman for Trinity Mirror said: "As we have consistently said all our journalists work within the criminal law and the Press Complaints Commission's code of practice."

The four civil damages claimants are Sven-Göran Eriksson, the former manager of the England football team; Coronation Street actress Shobna Gulati; Abbie Gibson, a former nanny for the Beckham family; and Garry Flitcroft, the former captain of Blackburn Rovers football club.

Shares in Trinity Mirror fell 18% on Friday, wiping £25m off its market capitalisation as high court judge Justice Vos announced he planned to manage the four phone-hacking claims. This followed a share price fall of more than 10% last Tuesday after news of the civil claims first broke.

The BBC is expected to conclude a deal this week that will avert the threat of Test Match Special being silenced, or at least grounded, for England's forthcoming series in India.

The Corporation has been standing alongside Sky in a dispute with the Indian cricket authorities who are demanding extra money to cover the costs of broadcasting facilities on top of the rights agreements that have already been negotiated with Star TV.

But unlike Sky, which has already made arrangements for its commentary team to cover the four Tests from their London studio, the BBC has been backed into a corner. It has stressed the importance of its commentators being able to convey the atmosphere from the ground, to emphasise the difference between its TMS offering and the coverage provided by sites such as TestMatchSofa.com, where the commentary is provided from television pictures along the same lines of Sky's Soccer Saturday programme.

That would seem to leave it in a weak bargaining position with the Board for Control of Cricket in India, and must raise questions about the value of an agreement for radio rights which does not guarantee commentators entry to the grounds.

The BCCI is reported to be demanding around £50,000 from the BBC to cover radio production costs at the four Tests in Ahmedabad, Mumbai, Nagpur and Kolkata – whereas Sky has been asked for 10 times that figure to install a studio with the necessary facilities for presenting matches from each of the grounds.

The England and Wales Cricket Board has been involved in the background but are anxious to maintain a low-key stance, partly because in this instance the BCCI seems to be receiving unfair criticism.

It is not signed any rights deals or contracts with Sky or the BBC, having sold global media rights to Indian cricket to Star TV, and are now acting as a production house. In the past, the TV channel that has owned the rights has also tended to control production, so such disputes have rarely arisen.

The BBC has not commented on the details of its agreement with Star, and will only say that negotiations with the BCCI are continuing. That is also the official position with Sky, although with little more than a fortnight until the start of the series it seems increasingly likely that its commentators will be staying at home – which could cause an additional problem for The Times newspaper, whose cricket correspondent Mike Atherton is also a member of the Sky team.

The constitutional crisis predicted for years by Professor Vernon Bogdanor is upon us. He warned that the human rights reforms of the 1990s created a potential conflict between the sovereignty of parliament and the rule of law. "What happens if there is a clash between the two principles?" he asked in his Magna Carta lecture of 2006. A very senior judge to whom he had posed the conundrum had replied "That is a question that ought not to be asked."

The UK have until the 22 November to respond to the verdict of the European court of human rights on prisoner voting; it is no longer possible to avoid the dilemma.

Thankfully, a judge of that court in Strasbourg has outlined to me a promising answer. Moreover, there are signs from the Strasbourg bureaucracy that the Council of Europe anticipates the House of Commons will refuse to accept the court's verdict on prisoner voting and that the Council, the parent body of the court, is prepared for a considerable period of negotiation.

If the UK is resolute in defending its sovereignty by refusing to kowtow to Strasbourg, I do not believe that any dire results will follow. Indeed, Strasbourg will come to see as being in its interests to give way on the fundamentally important issue of national independence. By sacrificing the aim of exercising absolute legal authority over 47 nation states, the European court of human rights stands to gain in moral authority. By aiming for less, it will gain the respect and legitimacy which it currently lacks.

Were the prisoner franchise issue faced by the UK parliament really about the voting rights of incarcerated persons, it would be fairly simple to resolve. The court has made it plain that the UK needs to agree to the most minimal form of compliance with the Strasbourg judges' decision that there cannot be a blanket ban on prisoner voting.

But recognition of the authority of Strasbourg, however flexibly exercised, is precisely what many MPs are now unwilling to give. If the House of Commons accepts the authority of Strasbourg in this relatively insubstantial matter, it will thereby accept its jurisdiction over a number of vital matters in the future. The majority of MPs now appreciate that the long-term effects of surrender to the sovereignty of Strasbourg could be dire.

The argument that the House of Commons has freely accepted obligation to accept the authority of the human rights court has worn thin. Even if it was a free agreement by our elected legislators in 1994, it does not represent the wishes of today's House of Commons. When the prisoner votes issue was debated on 10 February 2011, no more than 22 of the 649 MPs supported the Strasbourg judges.

While prisoner voting has brought the underlying conflict between Westminster and Strasbourg to the fore, there is a possibility that equally contentious issues lie ahead. The ramifications of the Kiss case on voting rights of those with mental disabilities have not yet been felt. Unwise obiter dicta of the Strasbourg judges in 2010 about Jewish brit milah (infant male circumcision) are already raising alarm.

There are two ways in which the wishes of the majority of our elected lawmakers may be respected and the UK simultaneously may honour its existing legal agreements. The first, more radical, is to renounce the treaty committing the UK to the jurisdiction of the European court of human rights. The UK is entitled to do this provided it gives six month's notice.

If the UK took this step, it would still be committed to honour the human rights provisions of the Convention since they are incorporated in the Human Rights Act (HRA). Crucially, this change would make it the sole responsibility of UK judges to adjudicate. Parliamentary sovereignty would be restored because the HRA allows parliament to override decisions of the UK judges, whereas the European Convention Treaty does not permit Parliament to override Strasbourg.

It is empty rhetoric to argue that withdrawal from the jurisdiction of the Strasbourg judges would discredit the UK. Not only has Britain an exceptionally good record of compliance with judicial rulings on human rights matters, it would remain committed to the rights set out in the Convention, albeit adjudicated by senior UK judges. Nor are threats that the UK would be forced out of the Council of Europe and the European Union realistic.

However, a second solution would be preferable. Britain could negotiate with the committee of ministers of the Council of Europe to amend the existing treaty. This would allow national parliaments to override Strasbourg decisions on general matters of policy. At first sight this idea may appear to be wholly destructive of the court. On closer reflection, the very opposite could be the result. This is what the Strasbourg judge with whom I have discussed the matter has indicated.

His reasoning is as follows. The greatest problem facing the European court is that some of the countries with the poorest human rights records regularly ignore its judgments. Were countries permitted to override decisions on those rare occasions when their parliaments voted to do so, the expectation would be automatic compliance by governments in all other cases. The overall effect would be increased compliance by the shaky new democracies which were accepted into the Council of Europe following the break-up of the Soviet Union.

The hatred of the Strasbourg judges of which Sir Nicolas Bratza, the outgoing president, has complained does not stem from misreporting. It is a reflection of the widening realisation by our elected politicians that a 47-nation foreign court with far-reaching authority over every British governmental body and over every piece of legislation is incompatible with a democratic system of government.

No credible system of international elections and accountability has been devised. In any case, the House of Commons has made it very clear that it does not wish to hand over its sovereignty.

Were Strasbourg to be so unwise as to impose a mass of small fines on the UK as retaliation for defying its demands on prisoner voting, British hostility would burgeon. Exit from the Strasbourg system would become more likely. By contrast, if the Council of Europe accepts the powerful case for making compliance with the court's rulings subject to national parliaments, the standing of the court and its effectiveness will grow.

A Greek journalist has been arrested for publishing the names of wealthy Greek citizens with deposits totalling €2bn (£1.bn) in Swiss bank accounts.

Kostas Vaxevanis, editor of the Greek magazine Hot Doc, published the so-called "Lagarde list." It's an electronic file given in 2010 by then French finance minister Christine Lagarde to the Greek government.

It names 2,000 Greeks with Swiss accounts who are regarded as potential tax evaders. Yet the Athens government is alleged to have failed to take any action in the two years since it received the information.

In a challenge to the authorities, a major Greek newspaper, Ta Nea, today reprinted the names. It devoted 10 pages to the list.

The centre-left daily said it was not leaping to any conclusions about "its content nor the connotations it evokes in a large part of the public." It stressed there was no evidence linking anyone on the list to tax evasion.

Vaxevanis, who argues that he was exercising press freedom by publishing the list, was arrested for breaching Greece's data privacy law by revealing citizens' private information, according to a police spokesman.

Greece's former finance minister, Evangelos Venizelos, said earlier this month that he had received the list in August 2011 from finance ministry officials and deemed that it couldn't be legally used.

He said he handed it over to the government, which passed it on to the country's financial crimes squad, SDOE.

George Papaconstantinou, who preceded Venizelos as finance minister, has admitted receiving the list from Lagarde.

The list has drawn criticism from both opposition parties, as well as politicians within the governing coalition. Most comments link the failure to track down possible tax evasion by those on the list to the government's preparations to introduce new austerity measures to secure international aid.

Britain's National Union of Journalists has condemned the arrest of Vaxevanis. General secretary Michelle Stanistreet said: "It is outrageous that the person who has unmasked wrong-doing has been arrested and charged. This is a blatant attack on the freedom of the press."

The NUJ will be working with its partner organisations, the International Federation of Journalists and the European Federation of Journalists, to register its condemnation of the arrest.
Sources: Bloomberg/Reuters/NUJ

It's often said that Oliver Knussen is a "composer's composer", or even a "musician's musician". He is revered by his peers and the younger generation alike for his perfectly formed, jewel-like scores and his wonderfully sharp and detailed performances as a conductor. But what's become clear to me, after a decade of working with him and performing his music, is that these scores are not just for composers or musicians.

Where the Wild Things Are and Higglety Pigglety Pop!, his extraordinary double bill of fantasy operas written with Maurice Sendak, will be performed as part of a Total Immersion weekend of Knussen's music at the Barbican to mark the composer's 60th birthday. They encapsulate everything one could wish for in a musical and theatrical experience: beauty, excitement, delicacy, zaniness. This is the ideal sound-world for anyone wishing to approach contemporary music for the first time. Where the Wild Things Are begins with young Max driving his mother to distraction with yet another fit of childish exuberance gone too far. Sent to his room with no supper, he miraculously finds himself on a voyage to a strange land where equally wild things live – monsters waiting to "gnash their terrible teeth and roll their terrible eyes". Max ultimately conquers the Wild Things and becomes their king, but before long, loneliness sets in and he craves home. The soup he finds on his return is "still hot", leading us to believe that the journey, "in and out of weeks and over a year", was all a dream.

Sendak's beloved sealyham terrier Jennie, and more specifically her death, provides us with the outspoken, loveable, histrionic heroine of Higglety Pigglety Pop! Dissatisfied with her comfortable existence at home, she too takes a journey, in this case to seek "experience". After a series of adventures involving, among others, a cat milkman and an implacable baby, she eventually finds experience in the mouth of a lion. Her reward is to be given the role of leading lady in the World Mother Goose Theatre's production of Higglety Pigglety Pop!, complete with props made of Jennie's favourite salami: the performances take place in perpetuity. Thus she finds the eternal canine happiness that Sendak wished for his own Jennie.

Taking fairy or fantasy stories as the basis for an opera is nothing new: Cinderella, Hansel and Gretel and Pinocchio have all been given the operatic treatment. However, the genius of Wild Things and Higglety, as with all great children's literature, is not so much that they are "for" children, as that they speak of and to children – "the only reasonably sane audience", according to Sendak. Children in his stories, as in life, live in an adult world that can be dark, frightening and lonely. In Max we are presented with a little boy who is by turns scared, courageous, hyperactive and funny, but nearly always badly behaved. Likewise, Jennie is never quite able to curb her tongue or her voracious appetite. But these heroes and heroines are all the more genuine for their imperfections. Max wakes from his tantrum-induced sleep to find soup left by a mother who of course loves him despite his faults, and it is Jennie's very real excesses that lead her to the World Mother Goose Theatre and eternal happiness. Both Knussen and Sendak approach their subject matter with a profound seriousness and without the slightest hint of kitsch. In the precision of their observations, these operas make no concession in either their musical language or theatrical content. They simply invite both children and adults to respond as they will.

Netia Jones's multimedia production manages to remain faithful to the vision of Knussen and Sendak while breathing new life into it. Prior to his death earlier this year, Sendak had discussed the project extensively with Jones and had given her carte blanche to animate his original drawings (quite an accolade from a man renowned for his guardedness and perfectionism). To give a taste of how this works, in performing the part of Max not only do I get to jump and tumble across the stage in the most perfect recreation of a wolf-suit, but you also see me jump into Jones's animations, where I cavort and interact with huge 2D monsters.

Over the years I've worked with Knussen I've come not only to respect the man, the conductor, the composer, but to value his friendship and to hope for his respect, too. In concert he allows his musicians space to breathe, to play with confidence, to have the benefit of the doubt; at the same time he is on top of every note and nuance, devoting the same fastidious care and attention to each work that passes through his hands. That's why he's a musician's musician. In 2006 I was approached by him to sing the premiere of his Requiem: Songs for Sue, written in memory of his late wife. It was a privilege, of course, but only when I looked in the published score and saw on the title page "written for Claire Booth to sing" did I truly realise what an honour I'd been given. However, there is nothing precious about him. During the flight to Chicago on our way to the first rehearsal, he handed me the score of the just-finished second song, a setting of Antonio Machado's "Los Ojos", and suggested we "talk to someone Spanish" on arrival to check it was OK. Far from inciting nerves, his last-minute approach proved thrilling, and Songs for Sue has gone on to be recognised, rightly, as a contemporary classic.

During the Barbican weekend devoted to Knussen's music I will be swapping wolf costume for concert dress and singing Requiem alongside his Whitman Settings, written in 1991 for the soprano Lucy Shelton. It's been a long journey from admiring recordings of his music as a university student to performing them with the BBC Symphony Orchestra (with whom Knussen is artist in association) and Britten Sinfonia in these concerts. I hope those who attend enjoy the rumpus as much as I know I will.

Claire Booth performs in Where the Wild Things Are and Higglety Pigglety Pop! on Saturday 3 November, and with the BBC Symphony Orchestra on 4 November, as part of the Total Immersion weekend at the Barbican, London EC2. barbican.org.uk

The megaphone is on, and it is blaring. From the pages of the Murdoch, Telegraph and Mail papers the message is the same: when Lord Justice Leveson reports in the next few weeks his verdict could spell the end of press freedom.

If the judge recommends a regulator underpinned by statute, they warn, we risk a historic error, placing us on a slippery slope towards state censorship. A sacred principle of British liberty dating back to John Stuart Mill, John Wilkes and even John Milton will be sacrificed.

Some who make this case are no doubt sincere (though I believe they are mistaken), but the editors and proprietors are not: they are a lot less interested in press freedom than in their own freedom to run their businesses without being accountable for what they do.

These are the same powerful people who expressed their love of freedom by participating in the cover-up of phone-hacking. For years they kept the story out of their pages and denigrated the Guardian and Nick Davies, who uncovered it. Press freedom in that case meant the freedom to hide unwelcome facts from their readers (which Rupert Murdoch once, long ago, called a newspaper's "power for evil").

For similar reasons most newspaper readers will have missed last week's news that in a poll for the Carnegie Trust and Demos 77% of voters wanted the press regulated independently (ie not by itself) – just as they probably missed another poll for Hacked Off a week earlier showing almost exactly the same thing.

Equally, most newspaper readers will not have noticed that the Daily Mirror and the Daily Mail were sentenced for contempt of court last week in a prosecution brought by the attorney general, Dominic Grieve. It was reported here and there in the press, but without fanfare. The Mail, for example, didn't consider its own fine worth more than six unapologetic sentences. It is none the less a shocking story.

In July, the court found the two papers guilty of publishing "highly prejudicial" material at a time when a jury was still considering its verdict on the attempted abduction of an 11-year-old girl. The judge in that earlier trial (of Levi Bellfield, who is Milly Dowler's killer) was obliged to discharge the jury and end the trial, leaving the victim and her family without justice – thanks to newspapers.

Would they do it again? Well, for the Mirror it was the second contempt-of-court conviction in 15 months. You'd be unwise to bet against it.

Press freedom, it is clear, is not to be confused with the freedom of newspaper readers to have fair and honest reporting about the papers they are reading and the people who operate them. How well or how widely reported were the new civil litigation cases against Mirror newspapers for phone hacking? Guess.

What threat does Leveson pose to the freedoms of these editors and proprietors? The likelihood is that he will propose a method of obliging them to adhere to a journalistic code of practice rather similar to the one they have already.

The editors wrote the existing code and it says for example that papers should be fair and accurate and that they should respect grief and shock. In the failed, fig-leaf world of self-regulation, the code's authors obeyed it only when they chose. Leveson isn't going to endorse that. We don't know what he will say, but it looks likely that he will give a new regulator teeth by underpinning it with statute.

For editors and proprietors that would indeed be historic, because for the first time they would be accountable for their decisions. The embarrassing forgetfulness they displayed at the inquiry could no longer cover their sins. "I was on holiday", would not be an excuse. For many ordinary journalists who want to do honest work in the public interest, this will come as a relief.

As for state control of the press, though papers flap about it nobody wants that, least of all Leveson, who insisted on the point at almost every public inquiry session. You won't be told this in most newspapers, but his terms of reference formally require him to make recommendations that support a free press.

So the image of Murdoch, Lord Rothermere, Paul Dacre and the Barclay brothers wrapping themselves in the flag of liberty is as repulsive as it is amusing. And at the same time they are working as hard as they can to bend David Cameron to their will.

When Leveson reports, Cameron must decide what to do. His position, pretty well in line with the Lib Dems and Labour, is that he will implement what the judge recommends providing it is "not bonkers". The editors don't like the sound of that and they are working on him, no doubt calling in all the debts and favours from cabinet friends that they can.

One of the problems that Leveson was asked to investigate was the undue influence of the press over politicians. It is at the very least ironic that the very same influence could now threaten the fate of his report.

With Anna Dello Russo working with H&M, the Sartorialist's Scott Schuman on his second book and Bryan Boy a judge of America's Next Top Model, no one needs telling that bloggers are now seriously influential. And they are turning that influence into cold hard cash.  

The names above are the blogging elite, so it isn't surprising that they have made blogs into brands. What is new, however, is emerging bloggers doing the same. Distancing themselves from the traditional concept of blogging as an impartial activity, they're realising there is money to be made through advertising, sponsored content and even, in some cases, becoming the face of a brand.

Helping this change along is a growth in middle men between brands and bloggers. Fohr Card is a new initiative set up by ex-Tumblr employees Holly Stair and Rich Tong as a kind of blogger store for brands. Launching next month in the US, brands subscribe to content that allows them to browse bloggers' work but also, importantly, to quantify it with follower counts and traffic statistics. "Our goal is to provide the tools to help brands identify content creators they would like to work with," says Stair. This way, they can get the numbers before making the deal.

Style Coalition is more of an agency for bloggers. It has worked with JC Penney on ad campaigns with bloggers, and partnered with Elle in the US. Its bloggers provide social media content for brands including Lancôme, Dolce & Gabbana and Gap. "It's harder for conventional advertising to get our attention these days," says founder Yuli Ziv. "Bloggers have readers who are loyal and go to that blog every day."

But will that continue once there is a commercial aspect to what they are reading? William Oliver, the co-author of Style Feed: the World's Top Fashion Blogs, believes so – as long as certain standards are maintained. "Blogs are obviously massively personal but we're so used to commercial content online, no one is fazed by it," he says. "The only time it becomes an issue is when readers feel the blogger's opinion is compromised." He says this is generally avoided by bloggers making a clear distinction between commercial and editorial content, usually through a "sponsored content" label, and things only become murky when that is blurred. "Because of the personal aspect, readers don't want to feel as if they're being lied to," he says. "There's a line that can't be crossed."

Navaz Batliwalla, who runs the Disney Roller Girl blog agrees. While she maintains that the cashing-in trend has yet to hit British blogs in a big way, she is careful about what she agrees to. "We're at a point where we're still figuring it out," she says. "It's important to check if it's not muddying the waters." Her own ventures into monetising her blog are subtle, such as an affiliates scheme that brings commission if someone clicks through her site to buy a brand's product. She has also worked with eBay, styling its lookbook for winter. "It's like a shop window," she says of her blog. "I work as a stylist and a writer, and work comes through it."

While Batiwalla says her work with Disney Roller Girl is part-time, some blogs start as hobbies but turn into full-time careers. Kat Griffin, who was a corporate lawyer before setting up her blog officewear blog Corporette, could give up her highly paid position when her blog took off, and with over 130,000 unique users every month, it had the potential to earn even more. "It's known that bloggers can earn six figures – and it's growing," says Ziv. "Bloggers are entrepreneurs these days – they have influence and power. Why shouldn't they earn money from it?"

The Junior Isa is a year old on Thursday – but the celebrations look like being low-key. They were launched on 1 November last year as a tax-free way of saving or investing for a child, but 12 months on all the evidence is that awareness of the new accounts and take-up are both low.

More than half (56%) of parents with children under 18 haven't even heard of them, according to recent research from kids' savings specialist Family Investments. And official government data shows only 71,000 accounts were taken out in the first five months.

But at the same time, mums, dads and grandparents clearly want to save, and are aware that with the cost of university rocketing and the huge sums required to get on the property ladder, it's more vital than ever to start planning.

The survey found that 92% of parents thought it important to put some money aside for their offspring.

While the tax benefits of Junior Isas are arguably pretty minimal for most, they do make investing for a child much simpler. Anyone can contribute – allowing parents, grandparents, relatives and friends to pay into a single plan.

However, because they have no control over the way in which the child can use their Isa money when they reach 18, some will want to go for a different type of account or investment. There is, of course, nothing stopping you from opening a traditional children's savings account.

First, some basic facts: They are long-term, tax-free and any UK child under 18 can have one as long as they don't have a child trust fund. Broadly, this means those born before 1 September 2002 or after 2 January 2011 are eligible. Both cash and stocks and shares Junior Isas are available, and your child can have one or both. They are offered by banks, building societies, fund management companies, stockbrokers and so on, and parents, family and friends can contribute up to £3,600 per tax year. The account is owned by the child, and the money locked in until he or she turns 18, though they can manage their account from age 16.

One of the first decisions people must make is whether to go for a cash account, or one where much, or all, of the money is invested in shares. If you are jumpy about "gambling" your child's cash on the stock market, about 30 banks and building societies offer cash Junior Isas.

Most people aren't aware of this, but the Halifax offers an impressive 6% interest on its Junior Cash Isa, provided mum or dad (or whoever the "adult registered contact" is) holds a Halifax cash Isa with at least £1 in it. Others paying a decent(ish) rate include:

• Nationwide's Smart Junior Isa – 3.25% variable until 31 January 2014. After this, the rate reverts to 2.1%. Nationwide is thought to be the biggest provider of cash Junior Isas, with 66,000 opened since last November.

• Coventry building society's Junior Cash Isa - 3.25%.

• The Furness and Mansfield building societies have cash Junior Isas paying 3.05% with Market Harborough building society paying the same on balances of £3,000-plus.

Of course, many experts argue that the stock market is where you need to be when it comes to investing over a long period (up to 18 years), because it's argued that shares almost always produce a better return than savings accounts. James Bateman, head of manager selection at Fidelity, says: "Because it is so long-term, many investors should consider higher-risk funds – and, in particular, generally equities over fixed income since historically, over long periods, the former have substantially outperformed the latter."

Several investment firms offer Junior Isa products specifically aimed at parents, such as Witan's Jump scheme, but you don't need to be restricted to those. If you are happy to make your own decisions, you can access hundreds, or even thousands, of funds via a "fund platform" such as Hargreaves Lansdown's Vantage service, Fidelity FundsNetwork or JP Morgan WealthManager+. The Guardian has a service called Guardian Investing, provided by Skipton Financial Services.

Danny Cox at Hargreaves Lansdown reckons that those investing for more than five years, and who are happy with some risk "can't go far wrong with an equity income fund" such as Invesco Perpetual High Income. If you were going to "spice it up" and were looking at a longer term – perhaps more like 10 years – he suggests an emerging markets fund such as First State Global Emerging Markets Leaders.

The top 10 most popular Hargreaves Lansdown Junior Isa fund choices are:

• Invesco Perpetual High Income
• First State Global Emerging Markets Leaders
• Invesco Perpetual Income
• Newton Asian Income
• Lindsell Train Global Equity
• Aberdeen Emerging Markets
• HL Multi-Manager Income & Growth Trust
• Aberdeen Asia Pacific
• Marlborough Special Situations
• Newton Emerging Income

When buying a stocks and shares Junior Isa, watch out for high management charges. There are funds out there with low charges, such as Fidelity MoneyBuilder UK Index, a tracker fund, where the annual management fee is just 0.1%

You can also do it yourself by using a discount broker such as Cavendish Online, which no longer charges an admin fee but, instead, takes a very small part of the AMC – in most cases 0.05% of the fund value.

Features are the centrepiece of any magazine or newspaper supplement – the stories given the most space to be deep and insightful, eye-catching and revelatory, absorbing and entertaining.

In this practical two-day Masterclass you'll get expert insight from writers and editors, and learn both the mechanics of feature journalism – from pitching to editing – and the art of writing a great piece.

This Guardian Masterclass will cover:

• making first contact with commissioning editors
• how to pitch (and how not to)
• analysing publications to work out what they're looking for
• different feature structures, treatments and formats
• tone and style
• how to improve your writing and self-edit

You'll leave with plenty of feedback, plus two feature pitches, and suggestions of titles to send them to. You will also be joined by guest speaker, Tom Lamont, writer and commissioning editor at the Observer New Review.

Tutor profile

Rob Orchard is the co-founder and editorial director of the Slow Journalism Company, the publisher of Delayed Gratification magazine, which revisits the events of the preceding quarter and makes a virtue of being "Last to Breaking News". He spends his days writing and editing long form features for the publication, which he describes as offering an "antidote to PR-driven stories, knee-jerk reactions and churnalism". Prior to starting the Slow Journalism Company, Rob launched and ran magazines for Virgin Atlantic, created the Middle East's biggest travel magazine and worked as the editor of Time Out Dubai, Time Out Croatia and Time Out Paris.

Speaker profile

Tom Lamont is a writer and commissioning editor at the Observer New Review. He began his career at Time Out magazine in 2004, moving to write for Observer Sport Monthly in 2008 before joining the newspaper's relaunched Review section in 2010. Roughly one in four of his interviews with popstars, actors, writers and sportsmen will involve the subject enquiring politely how old he is.

Testimonials for Rob Orchard

"Rob Orchard is not only one of the most amusing and entertaining features writers I've ever come across, he also edits one of the best magazines currently being produced in the UK." Tim Arthur, Editor in Chief, Time Out London

"Rob is a fantastic editor to work with due to the combination of his incisive intelligence, impressive knowledge range, and passion for understanding exactly what makes an article come alive. So few editors these days make it feel like your work with them is a collaboration, but with Rob it really is. There's a genuine sense that your writing goes on a journey which ends at a more satisfying destination." Rachel Halliburton is a freelance journalist whose work has appeared in Spectator, the New Statesman, Prospect, the Independent, Delayed Gratification, the Evening Standard and the FT.

"Rob is without exception the best editor I have ever worked with. If it weren't for his guidance, his almost otherworldly ability to sniff out what will work and what will crash and burn and his meticulous nature I would have fallen at the first hurdle. He's also a terrific journalist in his own right." James Montague, author and journalist working for CNN, the New York Times and GQ.

The clocks in Italy, along with those across the rest of Europe, went back on Sunday morning. Sadly they did not wind back to the glory days of Diego Maradona at Napoli, Paolo Maldini at Milan or even Alessandro Del Piero at Juventus. Instead, as La Repubblica's resident humourist Emilio Marrese noted under the headline "Vintage Sunday", we were returned only to a time when "[Silvio] Berlusconi insults judges and referees help out Juve".

Berlusconi had reacted furiously to his conviction for tax fraud on Friday – describing the verdict, which remains subject to two levels of appeal, as "political" and "intolerable". But his words were positively restrained compared to the ones used by the Catania president, Antonio Pulvirenti, after his team had a perfectly good goal chalked off in their 1-0 home defeat to the Bianconeri.

"Today we witnessed the death of football," said Pulvirenti. It was his contention that the goal had not been ruled out by the referee, but instead "was disallowed by the Juventus bench".

Certainly the officials' decision-making process in the 26th minute at the Stadio Angelo Massimino had left a lot to be desired. Gonzalo Bergessio was in a clear onside position when Nicolás Spolli met Giovanni Marchese's cross from the left with a downward header towards the right-hand corner of Gigi Buffon's goal. The ball struck the foot of the post and rebounded back out into the six-yard box, where Bergessio prodded it home.

Initially, the referee Andrea Gervasoni signalled that the goal had been awarded. The linesman Luca Maggiani, whose flag had stayed down, also began to walk back towards the centre-circle. Then he stopped and turned around, calling Gervasoni over for a conference. It quickly became apparent that the pair were also discussing the situation with the official behind the goal, Nicola Rizzoli, via their headsets. Approximately 45 seconds later, the call was changed – with Bergessio ruled to have been offside.

At first, confusion reigned – the stadium continuing to celebrate for some seconds after the decision was overturned – but that soon gave way to rage. It had not escaped the attention that, en route to the halfway line, Maggiani was confronted by Simone Pepe and other members of the Juventus bench, who had strayed to the edge of their technical area to protest over the goal.

Pulvirenti was in no doubt as to what he had seen. "The linesman had given the goal, but after the complaints from the bench the referee and linesman changed their decision and disallowed it," he said. "It is a scandal, it is embarrassing … Who decided [that the goal should not stand], Pepe or [Emanuele] Giaccherini? It is becoming hard to continue."

In reality, of course, it seems unlikely that Maggiani, a top-flight referee since 2000 and an international one since 2004, could have been intimidated by something as mundane as a screaming player standing in his way. Instead this was a mess borne of a lack of conviction in his initial decision. He had wanted to check with Rizzoli whether there was a touch inside the area by any Catania player after Spolli.

Rizzoli was clearly in no position to judge the offside, but could confirm that Francesco Lodi had got his boot to the ball as it flew through the area. For Maggiani this was decisive. When Spolli won his header Bergessio was onside, but surely by the time the ball grazed Lodi's boot the striker must have strayed off? The truth was that he hadn't – the player still clearly onside when the ball passed Lodi – but now the linesman's memory was playing tricks on him.

It was a decision only compounded in the second half, when the same official failed to spot that Nicklas Bendtner was offside in the build-up to Juventus's goal. This was a far more marginal decision, the striker's front foot just barely beyond the defensive line when he was played through by Mirko Vucinic. Bendtner failed to convert the opportunity himself – his tame first-time effort blocked by Mariano Andujar – but Arturo Vidal rolled home the rebound.

On its own it was an incident that might easily have been forgiven – even Pulvirenti saying he did not want to protest about that goal afterwards. But taken in the greater context of a match containing Catania's disallowed goal and eventually also a red card for Marchese (even if his two bookings were, in truth, merited), it all played into the old narrative of officials being subject to sudditanza psicologica – a "psychological slavery" – that causes them to inherently favour the big teams.

It was a thesis supported by results elsewhere. Prior to the Juventus game, the only goal in Serie A this weekend had been scored by Milan's Stephan El Shaarawy against Genoa – and that too ought to have been disallowed after Ignazio Abate strayed offside in the build-up. On Sunday night Chievo would be denied a penalty that could have earned them a draw away to Napoli when Sergio Pellissier was brought down by Hugo Campagnaro.

But on a bad day for officials all over the country (and beyond) it was not always the smaller teams who suffered. Lazio's appeals for a spot-kick were rejected when the ball struck Juan Cuadrado's outstretched arm in the area during their loss to Fiorentina, and the Biancocelesti subsequently also had Stefano Mauri's equaliser wrongly disallowed for offside. Roma's Zdenek Zeman accused the referees of having been decisive in his team's collapse from 2-0 up to lose 3-2 at home to Udinese.

"They always say that referees don't decide who wins the league," said Zeman. "In reality it seems to me that to a great extent they do."

The Juventus result, though, was always going to receive the greatest scrutiny – extending as it did their unbeaten run to 48 games. Beppe Marotta, the club's general manager, argued afterwards that his team would have won even if Catania's goal had stood, but while it is possible that would have been the case it equally might not. Juve dominated throughout against the Sicilians, but with Andujar in inspired form had never seemed certain of scoring.

At full-time, Juventus left the field to a chorus of "ladri, ladri" – "thieves, thieves", and it was not long before 'evidence' of a stitch-up was being circulated. Pulvirenti himself, who argued that there was "more than just sudditanza psicologica" at play, would claim to have seen a post celebrating Juventus's Scudetto on Maggiani's Facebook profile. In reality it appears that this was in fact just a 'fan' page, and likely set up by someone else entirely.

But it is easy for fans to assume the worst when so many of their darkest suspicions have been proven true in recent years – from Calciopoli through to the ongoing Calcioscomesse scandal. This was not so much a case of the clock being turned back for Serie A, as a simple maintenance of the status quo.

Talking points

• Juventus, then, potentially stand just six days away from completing a half-century of league games without defeat. If a visit from Bologna this Wednesday is unlikely to knock them off course, then the 50th match has the potential to be very challenging indeed. On Saturday Juve host an Inter side who have won all of their eight away games so far this season.

• Inter extended their general winning streak to seven in a row with a 3-1 victory away to Bologna on Sunday, a feat which has been bettered only four times in the club's history. The Nerazzurri are now up to third, just four points behind Juventus. Asked if his team could challenge for the Scudetto, the manager Andrea Stramaccioni, replied: "There are only nine games gone, so it's not smart to talk about objectives – only growth. That same growth Juve had last year: when they struggled at the beginning but then found their stride and went on to win the Scudetto." We'll take that as a yes, then.

• Lazio might have been unfortunate with some of the refereeing decisions during their defeat to Fiorentina at the Stadio Artemio Franchi, but that shouldn't take away from the quality of football played by the hosts, nor indeed their two exceptional goals. Adem Ljajic had opened the scoring with a fierce and unexpected drive back across his body from outside the box, before Luca Toni executed a stunning swivel and finish in the 90th minute. "Forget his date of birth," advised Gazzetta dello Sport's Luca Calamai. "Inside the area he can still make the difference."

• Likewise, Zeman's protests over a possible offside in the build-up to Udinese's second goal against Roma – as well as the disputable nature of the penalty award that led to their winner – should not distract from the fact that his team once again imploded in dramatic fashion at home. Just as against Bologna a month previously, Zeman's Roma had looked like they were on a different planet to their opponents as they tore Udinese apart with spectacular and incisive football in the first half-hour, but promptly came apart at the first sign of adversity. Adding insult to injury was Antonio Di Natale's match-winning penalty – a 'cucchiaio' of the sort that Francesco Totti had made his trademark at this very stadium.

• Are two managers better than one? That seems to be the conclusion in Cagliari, where the combined efforts of Ivo Pulga and Diego Lopez have led to three consecutive 1-0 wins since they were appointed to replace Massimo Ficcadenti. Pulga is formally the manager, with Lopez his assistant, though it has been suggested that this is more of a job share – with the latter unable to take the job alone on account of not having the required licences.

• Where would Milan be this season without El Shaarawy? The forward now has six goals in nine Serie A appearances this season. The rest of his team have four between them – and three of those were scored by Giampaolo Pazzini in a single match.

Results: Bologna 1-3 Inter, Catania 0-1 Juventus, Fiorentina 2-0 Lazio, Milan 1-0 Genoa, Napoli 1-0 Chievo, Pescara 0-0 Atalanta, Roma 2-3 Udinese, Sampdoria 0-1 Cagliari, Siena 0-0 Palermo.
